questions.question: Where a fuel jettison system is fitted to an aeroplane it must be capable of:

options.content: reducing the aeroplane mass from max take-off mass to max landing mass in 15 mins
reducing the aeroplane mass from max take-off mass to max landing mass in 10 mins
reducing the aeroplane mass from max take-off mass to max landing mass in 20 mins
reducing the aeroplane mass from max take-off mass to max landing mass in 5 mins

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the requirement of a fuel jettison system?

options.content: Free from fire hazards; discharges are clear of the aeroplane; fuel or fumes do not enter the aeroplane; control of the aeroplane is not affected by the jettison operation
Free from fire hazards; discharges are clear of the aeroplane; fuel or fumes do not enter the aeroplane; normal radio operation can continue
Free from fire hazards; discharges are clear of the aeroplane; fuel or fumes do not enter the aeroplane; must be safe to use in all weather/environmental conditions
The system must contain a protection device to stop the jettison as soon as the gear is lowered, and also to prevent all tanks being drained totally
is a procedure to reduce mass in an emergency only
is a procedure that may be employed to reduce aeroplane mass where an overweight landing may result in damage to the aeroplane
may be authorized by ATC to reduce delays by protracted holding procedures
may be ordered by ATC to reduce aeroplane mass in an emergency situation
over the sea and then only above 10 000 ft
over the sea, or over land above 10 000 ft agl
anywhere and at any height if unavoidable in an emergency
over the sea, or over land above 4000 ft in summer or 7000 ft in winter

questions.question: The following aeroplanes are required to have a jettison system:

options.content: all public transport aeroplanes
only public transport aeroplanes with MTMA greater than 5700 kg
all public transport aeroplanes requiring two pilots
all aeroplanes, except where the max landing mass exceeds the max take-off mass less the mass of fuel required for a 15 minute flight to land back at the aerodrome of departure

questions.question:
When jettisoning fuel, safety is an overriding consideration.

Which of the following lists correctly identifies items to be considered when planning to jettison fuel?

options.content: Smoking; HF Radio; operation of flaps/gear/slats; weather conditions
Height; speed; ATC clearance; weather; area
Time required; position; other aeroplanes; proximity of cloud; aeroplane attitude
OAT; wind direction; altitude; time of day; airspace restrictions; any other emergencies
passengers are restricted to their seats and strapped in
normal operation of flaps/gear and lift enhancers is permitted
HF radios may be used but limited to essential transmissions only
fuel flow from the vents is to be visually monitored (where possible)

questions.question: Once the fuel jettison is complete:

options.content: it is essential that the fuel remaining is balanced in the tanks and a revised endurance calculated
ATC is to be informed that jettison is complete
the NO SMOKING light is to be extinguished
normal food distribution service is to recommence
